answerText: Emily Dickinson[10] In another Dickinson poem, the speaker claims she has "heard" this in the "chillest land and on the strangest sea." That poem calls this "the thing with feathers that perches in the soul."
heading: NASAT |2013 | 8 | 11 | Literature | American | College
subject: Literature
question: Question: This poet described a creature that "stirred his velvet head like one in danger" in "A Bird came down the Walk" and compared a sunset to a housewife in "She sweeps with many-colored Brooms." For 10 points each: [10] Name this American poet better-known for writing lyrics like "I'm Nobody! Who are you?" and "I heard a Fly buzz when I died."
